text: testified as follows:
- - - EXAMINATION
Sir, state your full name for the record, please?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Richard M. Reiff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Mr. Reiff, I'm going to ask you a series of questions today about a fire that occurred at the Clemens plant back in 2016.  If at any time you don't understand my question, please let me know and I'll be happy to restate it again for you.  It's our responsibility to ask you questions that you understand.  All right? I'm going to ask you to try to keep all your responses verbal because the court reporter cannot take down nodding our head or shrugging our shoulders.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there anything that would prevent you from testifying accurately today?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Sir, can you tell us where you currently live?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I currently live at the 757 East Main Street, Apartment L302.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In front of you is a document which we marked as Exhibit 1, which is a copy of the Notice of Deposition and the subpoena.  Is that a copy, sir, of the subpoena --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- that you received?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you have at your house or in your possession any documents or anything that related to this fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Sir, could you just tell us your general educational background, please?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Two years college.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And where did you go to high school?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: North Penn High School.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where did you go to college?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Gwynedd Mercy University, it was Gwynedd Mercy College at the time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what did you study?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: History major.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did you leave Gwynedd Mercy?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I done it in spells, I didn't go two years straight.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Then I'll start over. When did you graduate from high school?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Can you just tell us from 1982 to the present what your general employment history is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, generally from 1982 I joined the service, I was in the Army, on active duty until April 1986.  And I worked at American Olean Tile after I was discharged.  And then I worked a couple places up in North Jersey, my brother, trucking company, which I don't even remember the names of.  And then I was -- excuse me, I'm sorry, it was before I went to the tile.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And then I was employed at St. Mary Manor for ten years from '95 -- '96 through 2006.  And my current employer, which is Wissahickon Park Apartments, where I've lived since then.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry, where do you currently work?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Wissahickon Park Apartments, they're owned by the DePaul Management Company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you actually do work for the apartment?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what kind of work do you do there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm the maintenance supervisor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you were in the United States Army, what type of specialty did you have or anything there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I actually had three different specialties.  My first one was avionics repair, second I was a ground surveillance radar crew, and the third I was an intelligence analyst.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And other than those two years at Gwynedd Mercy, have you had any other education or training after high school?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Fire department related, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to ask you that separately, so let's just stick with non-fire department, have you had any other kind of training or education or anything?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I had one like control class through work, like when I was at St. Mary's, electronic controls.  But that's basically been it as far as education.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, you mentioned fire department. When did you first become active as a volunteer fireperson?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: In December of 1988.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you been active since then?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  I had one five-year break.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Has it always been as a volunteer or --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, it's always been 100% volunteer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So in December of 1988 which fire department --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The Fairmount Fire Company of Lansdale.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Do me one favor, and let me try and finish my question before you start to speak, because the court reporter has got to do them separately.  Okay?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (Witness shakes head.)
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So what were the five years when you took a break from the fire department?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: '96 through 2001.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you first went to Fairmount, did they provide you with training?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you tell us basically the types of training that you recall having as a member of the Fairmount Fire Company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I took basic firefighting, Firefighting 1, Firefighting 2, interior structural attack, chlorine class, various hazmat classes, defined rescue.  A bunch of small things, you know, other classes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the Firefighting 1 and 2, where did you actually take those courses?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Montgomery County Fire Academy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you obtain like certificates --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- of completion from each of those?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at any time have you ever served as an officer of any type within the Fairmount Fire Company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you tell us when you first became an officer?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And in 2004 what was the first position that you held?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As the fifth assistant chief.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are those titles like the fifth assistant chief, is that a hierarchy so there's like the chief, a first, and then on down?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At that time the structure was chief, first assistant, second, through the fifth.  The fifth was, you know, the lowest ranking.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long did you stay in that fifth position?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was the fifth for one year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And after that what, if any, position did you have?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Then in September of 2005, you know, I was moved, went up to fourth assistant chief, fill in a vacancy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long did you stay in that position?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was in that for a year -- well, the remainder of that 2005 and 2006.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what happened in 2006?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: In 2006 I was voted out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you then come back in --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As a fire -- I'm --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Come back in in any position within the organization later?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm not sure if it was that year or -- I became a trustee, there -- I'm not exactly sure of the time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What were the responsibilities of the trustees?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Trustees are responsible for the building and grounds.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long did you remain a trustee?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Till I left the department.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And when did you leave the department?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: In July of 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why did you leave?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Personality conflicts.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And going back to, let's say, June of 2016, would you have been serving as any type of an officer for the fire company at that point?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  I was the first assistant chief at that time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did you first become the first assistant chief?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Either 2012 or 2013, that's -- I think it was 2013.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what is the responsibility of the first assistant chief?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As being directed underneath the chief, obviously I was the next one in line, you know, to fulfill the chief in his absence.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And if in fact there's a fire of any type, is it the responsibility of the chief to be there to direct the firefighting?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And if in fact he was absent, does it fall to the first assistant chief?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It falls to the first, if the first assistant chief is available.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell me, do you remember the fire here at the Clemens facility in June of 2016?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where were you when you got the call that evening?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was at home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how far is your house from the location of the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: A mile and three-quarters, maybe two miles, probably closer to the mile and three-quarter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you received that call, did you go to the firehouse or did you come to the scene?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I came to the scene.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Why did you do that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Because I was the ranking officer at the time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where was the chief at the time?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: He was at work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what time do you remember it being, approximately, when you got that call?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: About 25 after 11:00, between 20 and 25 after.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  When you drove here, when you drove to the scene, which direction did you approach the building from?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I came from off Canon onto 5th Street and I parked on the A/B corner of the building, on the opposite side of the street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You got to remember, we just have this typed record, so we have to try to make sure we're clear. So if I was standing on 5th Street looking at the building --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's considered the A side of the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And if I was looking like that, would you come to the property from the left side?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: If you're looking at the building, I came from the right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And where did you park your vehicle again?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I parked on the -- I passed the building and parked on the left-hand side of the road about half a block down.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as you drove towards the building that evening, what, if anything, do you recall seeing?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At that point I saw a fair amount of smoke coming from the back of the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you drive past the front of the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as you drove past the front of the building, what, if anything, did you observe in the front?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Very minor smoke condition.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you see any flames anywhere?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Only from the back of the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So as you approached, you could see flames in the back?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah, it's to the roof line at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you drove past and you parked your vehicle, what, if anything, did you do at that point?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At that point I exit my vehicle, got on my turnout gear, and I did immediately start to do my 360, which is basically you circle the building to check all conditions, you know, the entire perimeter of the building. I walked up what we considered the A side of the building, because I could see the B side from where I parked when I was walking up, and I came up past through the D and around the back to the C side of the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So is it accurate then that you walked, the first thing you did is walk along the 5th Street side of the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as you walked along that side of the building, there are windows and doors along there; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What, if anything, did you observe through those windows and doors?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At that point not much.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I mean, like I said, there was a smoke condition inside, but that was minor smoke coming from the -- actually light smoke coming from the eaves.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But as you looked through any of those windows, did you see flames?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: You couldn't see anything at that point, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you walk up 5th Street and then you made a left on Mitchell?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you walked down Mitchell Street and you looked at the building, what, if anything, did you see?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Nothing.  It was a solid wall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was there any visible flames there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was a solid wall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you got to the end of the building, you then made a left into the parking lot?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you describe for us what occurred, what you observed as you walked up the parking lot?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As I walked around the corner of the building, there's the first garage door was closed, there was nothing.  As I came around where the trailer was parked and looked to my left, looked at the building, the loading ramp, that's where the bulk of the fire was at that point.  That's where, you know, the fire was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So as you walked up the driveway, the first garage door was intact?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I think from what you said, was there a tractor, like a trailer from a tractor-trailer?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: A storage trailer, I assume it was, it was an old abandoned trailer or whatever. It was not in operable condition.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But it was basically what I would call like a 45-foot trailer from a tractor-trailer?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, a semi, full trailer.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you walked around that trailer, you looked to your left and you saw the fire there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, when I walked, yeah, the orientation of the trailer was backed into the building, and then that building jutted out at that point and the ramp into the building ran alongside that part of the building.  That's where the fire was, up at the top of the ramp.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you looked at the top of that ramp, tell us specifically what you saw?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At that point the overhead door was already failed, it was coming down.  It was totally engulfed in flames.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had it already failed or was it failing when you walked up?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It could have been either way. I mean, there was so much flame it was hard to determine if it was completely down, but you could see it was, the structure was compromised.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And were flames like rolling out at the roof line there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you looked in below those flames, what, if anything, did you see?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was flames from floor to ceiling.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was there flames from left to right as well?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: To the right you could see some fire.  To the left, you know, because of the building configuration, you couldn't see anything past that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At least I couldn't.  You know, like I'm --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what actions, if any, did you take at that point as the person in charge of the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I started directing the first-in engine to come to the rear of the building, you know.  We are going to use the hydrant that's located right there at the corner of Mitchell and the driveway to the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long were you standing there by yourself before that unit arrived?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I couldn't tell you.  I mean, in all honesty, in that situation time is not something I'm even looking at.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  And I assume that this is accurate, I just want to make sure, you were not taking any photographs at that time?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when that first unit arrived, do you remember which truck it was?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It would be Engine 14.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What, if anything, did you direct the people from Engine 14 to do?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Had them come to the rear of the building, the driver, you know, establishes the hydrant connections with one of the drivers, and I had the rest of the crew deploy the two-and-a-half-inch line.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you tell them to do with that line?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Basically, you know, start knocking down the bulk of the fire they could see.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you watch them as they attempted to do that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: With doing other things, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what results, if any, did they obtain when they tried to knock that fire down?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not a great deal of results.  It was just, the fire was well -- it was beyond what one hand line was going to do at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you instruct them to try to penetrate the building, to get inside?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I wanted them to get as close and make a penetration if they could, which they got as far as the top of the ramp.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did that unit also try to deploy a second hose at that spot?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Eventually there was another line, there were other lines pulled off the truck, yes, when the other -- as other apparatus got there, more crews got there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And what, other than that unit that came to the back, what did you direct the other units to do as they arrived?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Hatfield Station 17, you know, lay a supply line in from 5th and Valley Forge, because I knew the bulk of the fire was going to be needing a fair amount of water. Instructed the fire company was coming in, they were coming down, they came over, the first truck came in off of Camden Avenue down 5th Street, had them put the aerial in service to the front of the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long did the firefight operations take that evening?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, we were still here till 5 o'clock the next evening.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And when --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I mean in total.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was it that the fire was under control?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I honestly don't know what time.  At that point the chief had left work and he had assumed command.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know approximately when it was that he assumed command?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Like quarter after 2:00, 2:30.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And by the time that he had assumed command, can you tell me what you recall the status of the fire being, let's say, at 2:00 a.m.?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At that point it was just contained. I mean, there was no, you know, there was no material efforts at that point.  The part of the walls were starting, appearing to start to fail.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry, what was starting to fail?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Some of the walls, there was cracking developing in some of the walls.  I evacuated the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And had firefighters actually entered the building at that point?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where had they entered from?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Some of them had entered, the Hatfield crew had entered from two, maybe two garage doors down to the right.  And I know they had made an effort to enter from the 5th Street side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And how long did you personally remain at the scene?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was on the scene the entire duration.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So you were there until 5:00 p.m. the next day?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Approximately.  Like I said, it's two and a half years ago, three years ago, I'm not good on time.  But, yes, I was there till we cleared.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And after the fire was brought under control, were there a series of rekindlings or hotspots that occurred inside?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many times did that occur, do you know?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Two that I know of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And where were the two that you knew of?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Right inside the garage doors to the left, due to the rolled-up carpets.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So the garage door that you first came to, okay, there was a flareup that occurred inside and to the left there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: To the left, well into the building, but to the left side of that door.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how far approximately into the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: 25, 30 feet, maybe.  It was, I mean, it was -- I'm trying to remember.  I wasn't paying too much attention to distances at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure, okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was wherever they had their stored rolled-up carpets.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did that come to your attention that there was a flareup or problem at that location?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: You know, we had people out on the test line call, we may have had a fire watch. I'm not even 100% sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said there was two locations you recalled.  What was the other location?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was the same area.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So there were two flareups that occurred at that same spot; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At least two.  Two that I can speak to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And after the fire was put out, did you participate in any way in any investigation as to the --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just let me finish my question. After the fire was put out, did you participate in any investigation into the cause or the origin of that fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone ever have a discussion with you about what caused the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone after the fact interview you about what you observed?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Daveler is the fire marshal; correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did Mr. Daveler ever take a statement from you or interview you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did anyone from the Pennsylvania State Police ever interview you about what you had observed or what occurred?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At any time since then has anyone reached out to you and asked you for a statement or asked you to give a recorded statement about what occurred?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have no further questions.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: - - - EXAMINATION
Sir, when you approached the scene, did you hear any alarms?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's all I have.
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I don't have any questions for you.  Thanks.
speaker: MR. ACKLEN

text: I don't have any questions.
speaker: MR. MILLIS

text: No questions.
speaker: MR. REICH

text: No questions.
speaker: MR. SLATTERY

text: One more thing. There's going to be a transcript that's going to come out of this.  You have the opportunity, if you would like, to review that transcript and make sure that it was accurately transcribed or you can waive that opportunity.  Would you like to read it?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, I'd like to read it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So what is going to happen is the court reporter is going to mail you an official copy of the transcript, and at the back there will be a thing called an errata sheet.  Anything that you notice that's wrong, you put on the errata sheet.  You then sign the form and there will be an envelope there to mail it back.  You'll mail it back to her.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Witness excused.)
(Whereupon the deposition adjourned at 11:10 a.m.)

- - - CERTIFICATE I HEREBY CERTIFY that the proceedings, evidence, and objections are contained fully and accurately in the stenographic notes taken by me upon the deposition of RICHARD REIFF on August 19, 2018, and that this is a true and correct transcript of same. MADALENE FOSTER ROHDE Registered Professional Reporter
